title: 110_s3569
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Judicial Administration and Technical Amendments Act of 2008" and includes a table of contents. The "Judicial Administration and Technical Amendments Act of 2008" includes provisions such as changes in the composition of divisions in Tennessee, supplemental fees for jurors on lengthy trials, public drawing specifications for jury selection, assessment of court technology costs, investment of court funds, and conditions of probation and supervised release. The "Judicial Administration and Technical Amendments Act of 2008" includes changes in the composition of divisions in Tennessee, specifically in the Western District of Tennessee. This involves amending Section 123(c) of title 28, United States Code, to include Dyer and Dyersburg in the division. The amendments made by the "Judicial Administration and Technical Amendments Act of 2008" affect the composition of divisions in the Western District of Tennessee, including the removal of "and Dyersburg" from the second sentence. The effective date of these amendments is upon the enactment of the Act, with exceptions for pending cases and jury service. Additionally, a supplemental attendance fee for petit jurors serving on lengthy trials is introduced. The "Judicial Administration and Technical Amendments Act of 2008" modifies trial procedures, including reducing the time for trials from thirty to ten days. District courts are granted the authority to issue jury summons at their discretion, and public drawing specifications for jury wheels are revised to ensure transparency in the selection process. These changes will be effective starting October 1, 2009. The court's website and clerk's office will post notices explaining the process of drawing names for jury selection. Amendments are made to sections 1866 and 1869 of title 28, United States Code. Section 1920 is amended to assess court technology costs. Section 1920 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to update the provisions regarding transcripts and costs. Section 104 of title 11, United States Code, is also amended to repeal obsolete provisions related to certain dollar amounts in the Bankruptcy Code. SEC. 8. INVESTMENT OF COURT REGISTRY FUNDS.
    Chapter 129 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts to request the Secretary of the Treasury to invest court registry funds in public debt securities with suitable maturities and interest rates determined by the Treasury Secretary. The Director may designate the clerk of a court to exercise authority over outstanding marketable obligations of the United States. SEC. 9. MAGISTRATE JUDGE PARTICIPATION AT CIRCUIT CONFERENCES. Section 333 of title 28, United States Code, amended to include magistrate judges in circuit conferences. SEC. 10. SELECTION OF CHIEF PRETRIAL SERVICES OFFICERS. Section 3152 of title 18, United States Code, amended to appoint a chief pretrial services officer by the district court. SEC. 11. ATTORNEY CASE COMPENSATION MAXIMUM AMOUNTS. Section 3006A(d)(2) of title 18, United States Code, amended to include compensation maximum amounts. SEC. 12. EXPANDED DELEGATION AUTHORITY FOR REVIEWING CRIMINAL JUSTICE ACT VOUCHERS IN EXCESS OF CASE COMPENSATION MAXIMUMS. Amends various sections of title 18, United States Code, to include senior personnel in reviewing vouchers exceeding compensation maximums. SEC. 13. REPEAL OF OBSOLETE CROSS-REFERENCES TO THE NARCOTIC ADDICT REHABILITATION ACT. Section 3161(h) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by restructuring subparagraphs and paragraphs. SEC. 14. CONDITIONS OF PROBATION AND SUPERVISED RELEASE. Amends Section 3563(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code, regarding conditions of probation. SEC. 15. CONTRACTING FOR SERVICES FOR PRETRIAL DEFENDANTS AND POST-CONVICTION SUPERVISION OFFENDERS. Amends Section 3154(4) of title 18, United States Code, to allow contracting for pretrial service functions. Amends Section 3154(4) of title 18, United States Code to allow contracting for pretrial service functions and post-conviction supervision offenders. Additionally, it amends Section 3672 to authorize the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts to negotiate and award contracts for monitoring, treatment, and other necessary services for released individuals in the community. SEC. 16 amends Section 991(a) of title 28, United States Code, changing the authority from "Not more than" to "At least". SEC. 17 updates penalties for failure to appear for jury summons in Sections 1864 and 1866 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 18 addresses the place of holding court for the District of Minnesota. SEC. 19 amends Section 1875(b)(3) of title 28, United States Code, increasing the penalty for employers who retaliate against employees serving on jury duty to $5,000 per violation and may include community service.
